etymology.description: 好久 (long time) + 不见 (not see) = haven't seen for a long time.
etymology.interpretation: Used as a friendly greeting when meeting someone after a long interval. Its structure also inspired the English calque “long time no see.”
etymology.simplification: 見 was simplified to 见 in the character reform to reduce strokes; the rest is unchanged.

parts.english: a long time; quite a while; ages (colloq)
not see; be missing; disappear; not to be visible

examples.chinese: 好久不见，我们改天聚一聚。(好久不見，我們改天聚一聚)。
examples.pinyin: Hǎojiǔ bújiàn, wǒmen gǎitiān jù yí jù.
examples.english: Long time no see; let’s get together another day.

examples.chinese: 我在机场遇到老同学，第一句话就是“好久不见”。(我在機場遇到老同學，第一句話就是「好久不見」。)
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zài jīchǎng yùdào lǎo tóngxué, dì yī jù huà jiùshì “hǎojiǔ bújiàn”.
examples.english: I ran into an old classmate at the airport, and the first thing I said was “long time no see.”

examples.chinese: 好久不见的朋友终于回国了，大家都很开心。(好久不見的朋友終於回國了，大家都很開心)。
examples.pinyin: Hǎojiǔ bújiàn de péngyǒu zhōngyú huíguó le, dàjiā dōu hěn kāixīn.
examples.english: A friend I hadn’t seen in ages finally returned to the country, and everyone was very happy.
